articles.headline: Top Insurgents Escaped Prison Days After Iraq Took Over
articles.snippet: Members of a violent insurgent group were among a group that broke out of a maximum security prison, raising questions about the functionality of Iraq’s security system.
articles.abstract: Members of a violent insurgent group were among a group that broke out of a maximum security prison, raising questions about the functionality of Iraq’s security system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  An outsize ceremonial skeleton key traded hands last week in the official transfer of Camp Cropper, the last jail in Iraq that had been under American control. The Iraqi government was, one American general said, “equipped, prepared and poised to take over.”
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Omar Al-Jawoshy

articles.headline: 401(k) Fees Gain a Bit of Clarity
articles.snippet: The fees have long been murky, but new rules from the Labor Department will make the charges a little clearer.
articles.abstract: The fees have long been murky, but new rules from the Labor Department will make the charges a little clearer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The next time you receive your 401(k) statement, do this experiment: don’t just look at your latest balance. Try to figure how much you’re paying in fees.

articles.headline: Ad Rules Stall, Keeping Cereal a Cartoon Staple
articles.snippet: An effort to forge tougher advertising standards that favor healthful products has hit industry opposition.
articles.abstract: An effort to forge tougher advertising standards that favor healthful products has hit industry opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lucky Charms. Froot Loops. Cocoa Pebbles. A ConAgra frozen dinner with corn dog and fries. McDonald’s Happy Meals.

articles.headline: Credit Score Is the Tyrant in Lending
articles.snippet: Since the financial crisis, a borrower’s FICO score has become the only thing that matters to mortgage underwriters.
articles.abstract: Since the financial crisis, a borrower’s FICO score has become the only thing that matters to mortgage underwriters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The other day, a mortgage broker named Deb Killian called me, more or less out of the blue. Ms. Killian has been in the business since 1994. She and her husband run Charter Oak Lending Group, a small firm based in Danbury, Conn., that they founded in 1996. She is a member of the board of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers. By her estimate, she has closed more than 3,500 loans during her career.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Considers Risks of Gas Extraction
articles.snippet: Pennsylvania residents point to fouled wells, deformed livestock and poisoned fish near natural gas wells that blast underground rock with water and chemicals.
articles.abstract: Pennsylvania residents point to fouled wells, deformed livestock and poisoned fish near natural gas wells that blast underground rock with water and chemicals.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANONSBURG, Pa.  The streams of people came to the public meeting here armed with stories of yellowed and foul-smelling well water, deformed livestock, poisoned fish and itchy skin. One resident invoked the 1968 zombie thriller “Night of the Living Dead,” which, as it happens, was filmed just an hour away from this southwestern corner of Pennsylvania.

articles.headline: For Insurers, Fight Is Now Over Details
articles.snippet: Health insurers are lobbying over a rule that 80 cents of each dollar in premiums must be spent on patient welfare.
articles.abstract: Health insurers are lobbying over a rule that 80 cents of each dollar in premiums must be spent on patient welfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: The legislative battle over the health care overhaul ended months ago, but it is hard to tell from the intense effort now under way by insurance companies to retool a critical provision.

articles.headline: Doubts Persist as Most Europe Banks Pass Stress Tests
articles.snippet: The tests found that seven of the region’s 91 largest banks needed to raise more capital, but questions about how the tests were done left some skeptical.
articles.abstract: The tests found that seven of the region’s 91 largest banks needed to raise more capital, but questions about how the tests were done left some skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  A vast majority of European banks passed a round of stress tests meant to measure the likelihood that they could survive an economic or market calamity, regulators said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Condé Nast Is Changing Its Blueprint
articles.snippet: The magazine publisher intends to rely less on advertising revenue and more on other sources like subscriptions and fees for online readers.
articles.abstract: The magazine publisher intends to rely less on advertising revenue and more on other sources like subscriptions and fees for online readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the era of the $12 magazine subscription coming to an end?

articles.headline: Tesla Electric Cars: Revved Up, but Far to Go
articles.snippet: Elon Musk, who made a fortune selling PayPal, has poured a lot of his money into Tesla, the maker of electric cars. But it has been hit with delays, financial crises and a personnel soap opera.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk, who made a fortune selling PayPal, has poured a lot of his money into Tesla, the maker of electric cars. But it has been hit with delays, financial crises and a personnel soap opera.
articles.lead_paragraph: EARLY last year, Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla Motors, strode into a giant hangar outside Los Angeles, in fitted jeans, leather boots and a designer jacket. With electronic dance music blaring, he whipped a black cover off a shiny silver car: a prototype of the Model S, an all-electric sedan.

articles.headline: Will Zynga Become the Google of Games?
articles.snippet: As the hottest start-up to emerge from Silicon Valley since Twitter, Zynga, the maker of FarmVille and other games, aims to maintain its momentum.
articles.abstract: As the hottest start-up to emerge from Silicon Valley since Twitter, Zynga, the maker of FarmVille and other games, aims to maintain its momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO

articles.headline: Seeing vs. Doing
articles.snippet: In many cases, investigators are finding that Wall Street firms did nothing when they learned about problem loans or improprieties in lending.
articles.abstract: In many cases, investigators are finding that Wall Street firms did nothing when they learned about problem loans or improprieties in lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: “WHAT did they know, and when did they know it?” Those are questions investigators invariably ask when trying to determine who’s responsible for an offense or a misdeed.

articles.headline: Drivers on Prescription Drugs Are Hard to Convict
articles.snippet: The issue is vexing police because there is no agreement on what level of drugs in the blood impairs driving.
articles.abstract: The issue is vexing police because there is no agreement on what level of drugs in the blood impairs driving.
articles.lead_paragraph: The accident that killed Kathryn Underdown had all the markings of a drunken-driving case. The car that hit her as she rode her bicycle one May evening in Miller Place, N.Y., did not stop, the police said, until it crashed into another vehicle farther down the road.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: Trader’s Cocoa Binge Wraps Up Chocolate Market
articles.snippet: A hedge fund manager has all but cornered the market in cocoa, helping to drive prices in London to a 30-year high.
articles.abstract: A hedge fund manager has all but cornered the market in cocoa, helping to drive prices in London to a 30-year high.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  To some, he is a real-life Willy Wonka. To others, he is a Bond-style villain bent on taking over the world’s supply of chocolate.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: China’s Money and Migrants Pour Into Tibet
articles.snippet: China sees development and an enhanced security presence as key to stability, but the flow of people has deepened resentment among many Tibetans.
articles.abstract: China sees development and an enhanced security presence as key to stability, but the flow of people has deepened resentment among many Tibetans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LHASA, Tibet  They come by new high-altitude trains, four a day, cruising 1,200 miles past snow-capped mountains. And they come by military truck convoy, lumbering across the roof of the world.

articles.headline: Next Big Battle in Washington: Bush’s Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: The tax fight will serve as a proxy for the bigger political clashes of the year, including the size of government and the best way of handling the tepid economic recovery.
articles.abstract: The tax fight will serve as a proxy for the bigger political clashes of the year, including the size of government and the best way of handling the tepid economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An epic fight is brewing over what Congress and President Obama should do about the expiring Bush tax cuts, with such substantial economic and political consequences that it could shape the fall elections and fiscal policy for years to come.

articles.headline: Court Under Roberts Is Most Conservative in Decades
articles.snippet: The court’s center of gravity under Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has edged to the right, based on an analysis of four sets of political science data.
articles.abstract: The court’s center of gravity under Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has edged to the right, based on an analysis of four sets of political science data.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and his colleagues on the Supreme Court left for their summer break at the end of June, they marked a milestone: the Roberts court had just completed its fifth term.

articles.headline: BP Is Expected to Replace Chief With American
articles.snippet: Robert Dudley, an American, will take over leadership of the company after repeated stumbles by Tony Hayward in responding to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.abstract: Robert Dudley, an American, will take over leadership of the company after repeated stumbles by Tony Hayward in responding to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP’s board is expected on Monday to name an American, Robert Dudley, as its chief executive, replacing Tony Hayward, whose repeated stumbles during the company’s three-month oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico alienated federal and state officials as well as residents of the Gulf Coast.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline:
View Is Bleaker Than
Official Portrayal of War in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Some 92,000 reports from 2004 through 2009, disclosed by Wikileaks.org, illustrate why, after nine years of war, the Taliban are stronger than at any time since 2001.
articles.abstract: Some 92,000 reports from 2004 through 2009, disclosed by Wikileaks.org, illustrate why, after nine years of war, the Taliban are stronger than at any time since 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was written and reported by C. J. Chivers, Carlotta Gall, Andrew W. Lehren, Mark Mazzetti, Jane Perlez, and Eric Schmitt, with contributions from Jacob Harris and Alan McLean.

articles.headline: Pakistan Aids Insurgency in Afghanistan, Reports Assert
articles.snippet: Military documents reflect deep suspicions among U.S. officials that Pakistan’s spy service has for years guided the Afghan insurgency with a hidden hand.
articles.abstract: Military documents reflect deep suspicions among U.S. officials that Pakistan’s spy service has for years guided the Afghan insurgency with a hidden hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans fighting the war in Afghanistan have long harbored strong suspicions that Pakistan’s military spy service has guided the Afghan insurgency with a hidden hand, even as Pakistan receives more than $1 billion a year from Washington for its help combating the militants, according to a trove of secret military field reports made public Sunday.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Jane Perlez, Eric Schmitt and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Fraternity of the Wired Works in the Wee Hours
articles.snippet: Members of Nightowls gather in the wee hours with laptops and caffeinated beverages to work on pet projects and side ventures.
articles.abstract: Members of Nightowls gather in the wee hours with laptops and caffeinated beverages to work on pet projects and side ventures.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK  After college, most people do their best to avoid having to pull any more all-nighters. But for some, even after graduation, the wee hours of the morning are the most productive.

articles.headline: Khmer Rouge Figure Is Found Guilty of War Crimes
articles.snippet: The prison warden known as Duch received a 19-year sentence, likely to be considered lenient in Cambodia, in the first major ruling of the United Nations tribunal.
articles.abstract: The prison warden known as Duch received a 19-year sentence, likely to be considered lenient in Cambodia, in the first major ruling of the United Nations tribunal.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  A United Nations-backed tribunal on Monday found a 67-year-old former prison warden of the Khmer Rouge guilty of crimes against humanity and war crimes for overseeing the torture and killing of more than 14,000 prisoners. He was the first major figure to be tried in the murderous regime since it was toppled 30 years ago.

articles.headline: Industries Find Surging Profits in Deeper Cuts
articles.snippet: Having cut costs, employers want to keep profit margins high without rushing into hiring again.
articles.abstract: Having cut costs, employers want to keep profit margins high without rushing into hiring again.
articles.lead_paragraph: By most measures, Harley-Davidson has been having a rough ride.

articles.headline: Warren’s Candidacy Raises  a Partisan Debate
articles.snippet: Appointing Elizabeth Warren to the new financial post would please liberals and set off a confirmation fight.
articles.abstract: Appointing Elizabeth Warren to the new financial post would please liberals and set off a confirmation fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren last week won the endorsements of several dozen Congressional Democrats, two of the nation’s leading labor groups and her hometown newspaper, The Boston Globe.

articles.headline: Journalists, Provocateurs, Maybe Both
articles.snippet: A new activist-journalist churns out information in real time, and the damage is done before anyone has time to check.
articles.abstract: A new activist-journalist churns out information in real time, and the damage is done before anyone has time to check.
articles.lead_paragraph: Journalism, even in its most traditional forms, is not always neutral. Did reporters and editors at The Washington Post spend two hard years coming up with its “Top Secret America” series, a comprehensive pat-down of America’s expanding security network, merely as a by-the-way to taxpayers?

articles.headline: Exploring Algae as Fuel
articles.snippet: Dozens of bioengineering laboratories are trying to create superalgae that can be used to make diesel or jet fuel.
articles.abstract: Dozens of bioengineering laboratories are trying to create superalgae that can be used to make diesel or jet fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  In a laboratory where almost all the test tubes look green, the tools of modern biotechnology are being applied to lowly pond scum.

articles.headline: When Race Is the Issue, Misleading Coverage Sets Off an Uproar
articles.snippet: It is an open question whether conservative media outlets risk damage to their credibility when obscure or misleading stories are blown out of proportion.
articles.abstract: It is an open question whether conservative media outlets risk damage to their credibility when obscure or misleading stories are blown out of proportion.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last couple of days, Andrew Breitbart, a conservative Web site operator, has been called a liar, a provocateur, a propagandist  and even a race-baiter. But he says he knows who the true race-baiters are: some Democratic activists.

articles.headline: Marketing ‘Tron: Legacy’ Brings the Hardest Sell Yet
articles.snippet: By the time the movie arrives in theaters in December, Walt Disney Studios will have spent three and a half years promoting it.
articles.abstract: By the time the movie arrives in theaters in December, Walt Disney Studios will have spent three and a half years promoting it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  The futuristic movie “Tron: Legacy” is not just pushing the boundaries of special effects. It is redefining the Hollywood hard sell.
